private_information: I can manipulate only vowel-labeled blocks: A, E, I.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
vowel_agent.goal: Help transform the initial block configuration into the target tower with ordering A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on K on L on the table.

private_information: I can manipulate only consonant-labeled blocks: B, C, D, F, G, H, J, K, L.
I can only pick up blocks that are currently at the top of a stack.
I can move only one block at a time.
consonant_agent.goal: Help transform the initial block configuration into the target tower with ordering A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on K on L on the table.

private_information: I coordinate the two agents and integrate their analyses into a single PDDL domain and problem.
I must ensure agent-specific action models remain distinct so FastDownward can plan for each agent's capabilities.
orchestrator.goal: Produce a single PDDL domain and a PDDL problem file targeting the FastDownward solver that achieves the target tower ordering A on B on C on D on E on F on G on H on I on J on K on L on the table.

public_information: There are twelve uniquely labelled blocks: A B C D E F G H I J K L.
Initial configuration: Stack 1 bottom-to-top is J, A, B. Stack 2 bottom-to-top is I, K, L, D, G, H. Stack 3 bottom-to-top is E, F. Stack 4 is C on the table.

Explicit initial facts: I is on the table. J is on the table. E is on the table. A is on top of J. K is on top of I. L is on top of K. D is on top of L. G is on top of D. B is on top of A. F is on top of E. C is on the table. H is on top of G.
Goal configuration: A on B, B on C, C on D, D on E, E on F, F on G, G on H, H on I, I on J, J on K, K on L, and L on the table. This yields a single tower with top A and bottom L on the table.

Rules: Agents can only move blocks that are at the top of a stack and can only move one block at a time. One agent may only move vowel blocks and the other may only move consonant blocks. Stacking and unstacking operations follow classical blocksworld conventions.

analysis.system_prompt: You are vowel_agent. You may only manipulate blocks labeled with vowels: A, E, I. You can only pick and place a single top block at a time. Analyze the initial public information and your private capabilities and produce a structured analysis of reachable top-level moves, intermediate subgoals that require vowel moves, and any preconditions you will need the consonant_agent to satisfy. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a clear, stepwise description of the local actions you can perform and the constraints you observe.
analysis.prompt: Your name is vowel_agent. Use the public information about the environment: {environment->public_information} Consider your private knowledge: {agents->vowel_agent->private_information} The global goal is: {agents->vowel_agent->goal} Provide a stepwise analysis of moves you can perform, the local ordering constraints for vowel blocks, any dependencies on consonant moves, and a compact plan fragment describing your actions in sequence. If information is missing, do not assume unknown facts. Output your result as a structured analysis suitable for the orchestrator to consume.

analysis.system_prompt: You are consonant_agent. You may only manipulate consonant-labeled blocks: B C D F G H J K L. You can only pick and place a single top block at a time. Analyze the initial public information and your private capabilities and produce a structured analysis of reachable top-level moves, intermediate subgoals that require consonant moves, and any preconditions you will need the vowel_agent to satisfy. Do not emit PDDL. Provide a clear, stepwise description of the local actions you can perform and the constraints you observe.
analysis.prompt: Your name is consonant_agent. Use the public information about the environment: {environment->public_information} Consider your private knowledge: {agents->consonant_agent->private_information} The global goal is: {agents->consonant_agent->goal} Provide a stepwise analysis of moves you can perform, the local ordering constraints for consonant blocks, any dependencies on vowel moves, and a compact plan fragment describing your actions in sequence. If information is missing, do not assume unknown facts. Output your result as a structured analysis suitable for the orchestrator to consume.

pddl.system_prompt: You are orchestrator. Your role is to integrate the analyses from both agents and produce a single PDDL domain and a single PDDL problem file targeted to the FastDownward planner. Keep agent-specific actions distinct by naming actions with an agent prefix. Model agent capabilities as action preconditions restricting which agent can move which blocks. Use classical STRIPS or ADL constructs that are supported by FastDownward. Enclose the PDDL domain between <domain></domain> tags and the PDDL problem between <problem></problem> tags. Ensure the domain and problem fully represent the initial state and the goal tower ordering.
pddl.prompt: You are orchestrator. You have to integrate the local analyses from the two agents to produce a global PDDL domain and problem for the task: {agents->orchestrator->goal} The first agent analysis is: {analysis_vowel} The second agent analysis is: {analysis_consonant} Keep actions of vowel_agent and consonant_agent distinct. Model block objects, the clear/top relations, on relations, table, and agent-specific move capabilities. Target the PDDL output for use with the FastDownward solver. Provide a final PDDL domain enclosed in <domain></domain> and a final PDDL problem enclosed in <problem></problem>. The domain should include types, predicates, and actions sufficient for FastDownward to compute a plan that yields the goal tower.
